questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 4-month history of headaches and neck pain. The patient describes the headaches as dull throbbing pain on her forehead. On questioning, she reports that the headaches and neck pain began after she was hit on the side of the head with a ball during soccer practice. The patient appears uncomfortable during the examination and mentions that her head feels "misaligned.” Physical examination reveals:

Asymmetry of the cranial bones on palpation
Left-sided temple swelling
Shifting of the index fingers to the right and the little fingers to the left during the vault hold

Which of the following sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) somatic dysfunctions is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lateral strain is a type of pathological strain pattern characterized by lateral deviation of the sphenoid relative to the occiput. Following the deviation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. Lateral strains are named according to the direction of the lateral deviation of the sphenoid base. In a right lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers would move to the left while the little fingers would move to the right, indicating deviation of the sphenoid to the right.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Vertical strain is a type of pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around their own transverse axes. This disrupts normal flexion and extension at the SBS. Vertical strains are named according to the position of the base of the sphenoid relative to the occiput at the SBS. The rotational movement of the sphenoid and occiput in an inferior vertical strain results in the base of the sphenoid being inferior to the occiput at the SBS. In the vault hold, the examiner's index fingers would move superiorly, while their little fingers would move inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) CORRECT:

Lateral strain is a type of pathological strain pattern characterized by lateral deviation of the sphenoid relative to the occiput. Following the deviation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. Lateral strains are named according to the direction of the lateral deviation of the sphenoid base at the SBS. In a left lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers (which palpate the greater wings of the sphenoid) move to the right while the little fingers (which palpate the squamous part of the occiput) move to the left in the vault hold, indicating deviation of the sphenoid to the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern that occurs when there is twisting at the SBS. In a left torsion, the sphenoid rotates left while the occiput rotates right around an anteroposterior axis. During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's left index and little fingers would move freely superiorly, while the right index and little fingers would move freely inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern that occurs when there is a twisting at the SBS. In a right torsion, the sphenoid rotates right while the occiput rotates left around an anteroposterior axis. During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's right index and little fingers would move freely superiorly, while the left index and little fingers would move freely inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: In this strain pattern, the cranium can appear like a parallelogram on palpation.

questions.text: A 4-week-old boy is brought to your office by his mother for a health maintenance examination. The mother reports that the pregnancy was normal and the delivery was uncomplicated. She consents to an osteopathic examination of her child. During the structural examination, you notice that the patient's head appears parallelogram shaped with flattening on one side. In the vault hold, your index fingers move to the left and your little fingers move to the right. Which of the following sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) dysfunctions is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lateral strain is a type of pathological strain pattern characterized by lateral deviation of the sphenoid relative to the occiput. Following the deviation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. Lateral strains are named according to the direction of the lateral deviation of the sphenoid base. In a left lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers would move to the right while the little fingers would move to the left, indicating deviation of the sphenoid to the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern that occurs when there is twisting at the SBS. In a left torsion, the sphenoid rotates clockwise while the occiput rotates counterclockwise around an anteroposterior axis. During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's left index and little fingers would move freely superiorly, while the right index and little fingers would move freely inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern that occurs when there is a twisting at the SBS. In a right torsion, the sphenoid rotates counterclockwise while the occiput rotates clockwise around an anteroposterior axis. During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's right index and little fingers would move freely superiorly, while the left index and little fingers would move freely inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) INCORRECT:

Vertical strain is a type of pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around their own transverse axes. This disrupts normal flexion and extension at the SBS. Vertical strains are named according to the position of the base of the sphenoid relative to the occiput at the SBS. The rotational movement of the sphenoid and occiput in an inferior vertical strain results in the base of the sphenoid being inferior to the occiput at the SBS. In the vault hold, the examiner's index fingers would move superiorly, while their little fingers would move inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) CORRECT:

Lateral strain of the SBS is a type of pathological strain pattern characterized by lateral deviation of the sphenoid bone relative to the occiput. Following the deviation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. Lateral strains are named according to the direction of the lateral deviation of the sphenoid base. In a patient with a right lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers (which palpate the greater wings of the sphenoid) move to the left while the little fingers (which palpate the squamous part of the occiput) move to the right in the vault hold, indicating deviation of the sphenoid to the right. Lateral strains are usually the result of trauma (e.g., during birth) and can cause the head to appear parallelogram shaped.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

Vertical strain is a type of pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around their own transverse axes. This disrupts normal flexion and extension at the SBS. Vertical strains are named according to the position of the base of the sphenoid relative to the occiput at the SBS. The rotational movement of the sphenoid and occiput in a superior vertical strain results in the base of the sphenoid being superior to the occiput at the SBS. In the vault hold, the examiner's index fingers would move inferiorly, while their little fingers would move superiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: In this SBS dysfunction, the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to the clinic because of persistent headaches and neck pain for the past week. He describes the headaches as dull, pressing, and accompanied by dizziness. He has been taking ibuprofen when the pain is particularly severe. He recently underwent a root canal and tooth extraction. The patient denies any recent illness or allergies. On structural examination, there is tenderness to palpation on the left side of the cranium and limited cervical range of motion. During the vault hold, the physician's hands twist in opposite directions. The left index finger is positioned superior (closer to the physician) than the right index finger, and the right little finger is superior (closer to the physician) than the left. Which of the following is the most likely sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) dysfunction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation of the SBS is a physiological strain pattern characterized by two motions occurring simultaneously in three separate axes. In right sidebending and rotation, the examiner's right index finger and little finger spread apart and move inferiorly, while the left index finger and little finger move closer together and superiorly during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation of the SBS is a physiological strain pattern characterized by two motions occurring simultaneously in three separate axes. In left sidebending and rotation, the examiner's left index finger and little finger spread apart and move inferiorly, while the right index finger and little finger move closer together and superiorly during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral strain of the SBS is a pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid deviates laterally relative to the occiput. This deviation is followed by rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. In right lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers move to the left while the little fingers move to the right during the cranial vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) CORRECT:

Torsion of the SBS is a physiological cranial strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in opposite directions around an anteroposterior axis (AP axis). Torsions are named after the greater wing of the sphenoid that is more superior. In left torsion, the sphenoid rotates clockwise around the AP axis when viewed from posterior, causing the left greater wing of the sphenoid to move superiorly, and the occiput rotates counterclockwise around the AP axis. The examiner's left index finger, which palpates the greater wing of the sphenoid, is positioned higher than the right and the right little finger, which palpates the squamous part of the occiput, is positioned higher than the left during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Lateral strain of the SBS is a pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid deviates laterally relative to the occiput. This deviation is followed by rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. In left lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers move to the right while the little fingers move to the left during the cranial vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

In right torsion, the examiner's right index finger is positioned higher than the left and the left little finger is positioned higher than the right during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: The cranial vault hold reveals that the greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior on the left compared to the right.

questions.text: A 4-week-old boy is brought to the office for a health maintenance examination. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother states that she experienced prolonged labor but denies any other complications. On structural examination, there is mild cranial asymmetry. During the vault hold, the physician's hands twist in opposite directions. The right index finger is positioned superior (closer to the physician) than the left index finger, while the left little finger is superior (closer to the physician) than the right. The most likely cranial strain pattern is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lateral strain of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) is a pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid deviates laterally relative to the occiput. This deviation is followed by rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. In left lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers move to the right while the little fingers move to the left during the cranial vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) is a physiological strain pattern that causes cranial asymmetry. Sidebending and rotation is characterized by two motions occurring simultaneously in three separate axes. In left sidebending and rotation, the examiner's left index finger and little finger spread apart and move inferiorly, while the right index finger and little finger move closer together and superiorly during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral strain of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) is a pathological strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid deviates laterally relative to the occiput. This deviation is followed by rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around two parallel vertical axes. In right lateral strain, the examiner's index fingers move to the left while the little fingers move to the right during the cranial vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) CORRECT:

Torsion of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) is a physiological cranial strain pattern that occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in opposite directions around an anteroposterior axis (AP axis). Torsions of the SBS are named after the greater wing of the sphenoid that is more superior. In right torsion, the sphenoid rotates counterclockwise around the AP axis when viewed from posterior, causing the right greater wing of the sphenoid to move superiorly, and the occiput rotates clockwise around the AP axis. The examiner's right index finger, which palpates the greater wing of the sphenoid, is positioned higher than the left and the left little finger, which palpates the squamous part of the occiput, is positioned higher than the right during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) is a physiological strain pattern that causes cranial asymmetry. Sidebending and rotation is characterized by two motions occurring simultaneously in three separate axes. In right sidebending and rotation, the examiner's right index finger and little finger spread apart and move inferiorly, while the left index finger and little finger move closer together and superiorly during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

In left torsion, the examiner's left index finger is positioned higher than the right and the right little finger is positioned higher than the left during the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: The cranial vault hold reveals that the greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior on the right compared to the left.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man arrives at the emergency department after being involved in a fistfight 6 hours ago. He recalls receiving a punch to the head during the fight. He reports a persistent headache and dizziness since the incident. Over-the-counter analgesics have provided no relief. The patient denies loss of consciousness or any other trauma. Vital signs are within normal limits. On neurologic examination, cranial nerves I–XII are intact, and muscle strength, sensation, and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Vault hold reveals symmetric, caudad movement of the physician's index fingers, while their little fingers move in a cephalad direction. Which of the following is the most likely sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) dysfunction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern characterized by twisting at the SBS, i.e., the sphenoid and occiput rotate in opposite directions on an anteroposterior axis (AP axis). This pattern often results from trauma to the top or bottom of the head. Torsion can occur either to the right or to the left, and torsions are named according to which greater wing of the sphenoid is superior. In a left torsion, the sphenoid rotates clockwise, causing the left greater wing of the sphenoid to be more superior than the right, while the occiput rotates counterclockwise around the AP axis. During the vault hold, the physician's left index finger is positioned higher than the right and the right little finger is higher than the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Although flexion is a physiological component of cranial movement, a pathological strain pattern occurs when the SBS is in a position of excessive flexion. During flexion and extension of the SBS, the sphenoid and the occiput rotate in opposite directions around two transverse axes. In a patient with a flexion dysfunction, vault hold would result in the physician's fingers spreading apart and moving caudad due to restricted extension as the SBS moves cephalad. In this patient, the findings on vault hold are consistent with flexion of the sphenoid accompanied by extension of the occiput at the SBS.
Image Description:

Demonstration of flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel axes.

The primary physiologic motion is between the articulation of the sphenoid and the occiput, which moves in a biphasic cycle in response to the pull of the reciprocal tension membrane and the fluctuations of the CSF. During flexion, the sphenoid rotates anteriorly while the occiput rotates posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. During extension, the sphenoid rotates posteriorly while the occiput rotates anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral strains are pathological strain patterns characterized by the lateral deviation of the sphenoid relative to the occiput. This deviation is followed by a rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around parallel vertical axes. This strain pattern is named according to the position of the sphenoid base at the SBS relative to the occiput. For example, in a left lateral strain, the sphenoid is deviated to the left. During vault hold, the physician's index fingers would move to the right and their little fingers would move to the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) CORRECT:

Vertical strains are pathological SBS strain patterns characterized by rotation of the sphenoid and the occiput in the same direction around two transverse axes. This strain pattern is named according to the position of the sphenoid base at the SBS relative to the occiput. In a superior vertical strain, the sphenoid rotates forward, causing the greater wings of the sphenoid to move inferiorly (i.e., caudad) and the base of the sphenoid to move superiorly (i.e., cephalad). The occiput rotates in the same direction, causing the basilar part of the occiput to move inferiorly. These motions result in the sphenoid base being positioned superior to the occiput at the SBS. During vault hold, the physician palpates the greater wings of the sphenoid moving inferiorly (index fingers move caudad) and the squamous part of the occiput moving superiorly (little fingers move cephalad).
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Compression is a pathological strain pattern often resulting from trauma to the front or back of the head. In compression, the sphenoid and occiput are pushed toward each other. Therefore, a vault hold would reveal restricted flexion and extension, and a diminished or absent cranial rhythmic impulse (CRI).
Image Description:

Demonstration of compression (restriction of motion) at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis.

In compression, the movement of the sphenoid and occiput is restricted. Lateral compressions can also be present that cause unilateral impaction.
questions.hint: In this type of SBS dysfunction, the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction. The strain pattern is named according to the position of the sphenoid base relative to the occiput.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the office with a 10-day history of headaches located at the back of the head and occasional dizziness. She recalls hitting the front of her head against a car door frame 2 weeks ago. Over-the-counter analgesics have provided partial relief. She denies nausea or loss of consciousness. Past medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, cranial nerves are intact. On vault hold, the physician's index fingers move cephalad and their little fingers move caudad. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) somatic dysfunction?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a superior vertical strain, the sphenoid base is superior to the occiput at the SBS. During vault hold, the physician palpates the greater wings of the sphenoid moving inferiorly (index fingers move caudad) and the squamous part of the occiput moving superiorly (little fingers move cephalad).
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Although extension is a physiological component of cranial movement, a pathological strain pattern occurs when the SBS is in a position of excessive extension. During extension of the SBS, the sphenoid and the occiput rotate in opposite directions around two transverse axes. In a patient with an extension dysfunction, vault hold would result in the physician's fingers moving together and cephalad due to restricted cranial flexion as the SBS moves caudad. In this patient, the findings on vault hold are consistent with extension of the sphenoid accompanied by flexion of the occiput at the SBS.
Image Description:

Demonstration of flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel axes.

The primary physiologic motion is between the articulation of the sphenoid and the occiput, which moves in a biphasic cycle in response to the pull of the reciprocal tension membrane and the fluctuations of the CSF. During flexion, the sphenoid rotates anteriorly while the occiput rotates posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. During extension, the sphenoid rotates posteriorly while the occiput rotates anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern characterized by twisting at the SBS, i.e., the sphenoid and occiput rotate in opposite directions on an anteroposterior axis (AP axis). Torsion can occur either to the right or to the left, and torsions are named according to which greater wing of the sphenoid is superior. In a right torsion, the sphenoid rotates counterclockwise, causing the right greater wing of the sphenoid to be more superior than the left, while the occiput rotates clockwise around the AP axis. During the vault hold, the physician's right index finger is positioned higher than the left and the left little finger is higher than the right.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) CORRECT:

Vertical strains are pathological SBS strain patterns characterized by rotation of the sphenoid and the occiput in the same direction around two transverse axes. This strain pattern is named according to the position of the sphenoid base at the SBS relative to the occiput. In an inferior vertical strain, the sphenoid rotates backward, causing the greater wings of the sphenoid to move superiorly (i.e., cephalad) and the base of the sphenoid to move inferiorly (i.e., caudad). The occiput rotates in the same direction, causing the basilar part of the occiput to move superiorly. These motions result in the sphenoid base being positioned inferior to the occiput at the SBS. During vault hold, the physician palpates the greater wings of the sphenoid moving superiorly (index fingers move cephalad) and the squamous part of the occiput moving inferiorly (little fingers move caudad).
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Although flexion is a physiological component of cranial movement, a pathological strain pattern occurs when the SBS is in a position of excessive flexion. During flexion of the SBS, the sphenoid and the occiput rotate in opposite directions around two transverse axes. In a patient with a flexion dysfunction, vault hold would result in the physician's fingers spreading apart and moving caudad due to restricted extension as the SBS moves cephalad. In this patient, the findings on vault hold are consistent with extension of the sphenoid accompanied by flexion of the occiput at the SBS.
Image Description:

Demonstration of flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel axes.

The primary physiologic motion is between the articulation of the sphenoid and the occiput, which moves in a biphasic cycle in response to the pull of the reciprocal tension membrane and the fluctuations of the CSF. During flexion, the sphenoid rotates anteriorly while the occiput rotates posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. During extension, the sphenoid rotates posteriorly while the occiput rotates anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

Lateral strains are pathological strain patterns characterized by the lateral deviation of the sphenoid relative to the occiput. This deviation is followed by a rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around parallel vertical axes. This strain pattern is named according to the position of the sphenoid base at the SBS relative to the occiput. For example, in a left lateral strain, the sphenoid is deviated to the left. During vault hold, the physician's index fingers would move to the right and their little fingers would move to the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a right and left lateral strain at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 vertical axis.

In a right lateral strain (greater wing to the left), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basiocciput move leftward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears right (shown with green arrows).

In a left lateral strain (greater wing to the right), the greater wings of the sphenoid and the basicocciput move rightward around the vertical axis (shown with orange arrows) while the basisphenoid shears left (shown with green arrows).

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: In this SBS strain pattern, the sphenoid and occiput are rotated in the same direction around two transverse axes.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the office with a persistent headache following a motor vehicle accident. He reports that he struck his forehead on the windshield. The headache is located in the occipital region and is accompanied by a feeling of pressure behind the eyes. The patient denies any loss of consciousness, vomiting, or visual disturbances after the accident. His past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Physical examination reveals:

No focal neurologic deficits
Contusion on the forehead without lacerations or active bleeding
Restricted flexion and extension of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) on vault hold
Low rate and amplitude of the cranial rhythmic impulse (CRI)

Which of the following SBS dysfunctions is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsion of the SBS is a strain pattern characterized by a twisting motion, in which the sphenoid and the occiput are rotated in opposite directions along an anteroposterior axis. Although torsion of the SBS can result from head trauma, vault hold would result in the examiner's fingers moving higher on one side, indicating that one greater wing of the sphenoid is positioned more superiorly than the other.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Although flexion and extension are physiological components of SBS motion, a pathological strain pattern can occur. A flexion dysfunction of the SBS typically manifests with restricted extension but with no restriction in flexion.
Image Description:

Demonstration of flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel axes.

The primary physiologic motion is between the articulation of the sphenoid and the occiput, which moves in a biphasic cycle in response to the pull of the reciprocal tension membrane and the fluctuations of the CSF. During flexion, the sphenoid rotates anteriorly while the occiput rotates posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. During extension, the sphenoid rotates posteriorly while the occiput rotates anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Sidebending/rotation of the SBS is a strain pattern characterized by simultaneous sidebending and rotation of the sphenoid and occiput along three axes. Sidebending occurs to opposite directions around two vertical axes, one passing through the foramen magnum and the other through the center of the sphenoid, causing the SBS to deviate either to the left or to the right. Rotation of the sphenoid and occiput occurs in the same direction along an anteroposterior axis. Although sidebending/rotation of the SBS can result from head trauma, vault hold would result in one of the physician's hands moving inferiorly with fingers spreading apart (indicating convexity) and the opposite hand moving superiorly with fingers pushing together (indicating concavity).
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) INCORRECT:

Although flexion and extension are physiological components of SBS motion, a pathological strain pattern can occur. An extension dysfunction of the SBS typically manifests with restricted flexion of the SBS but with no restriction in extension.
Image Description:

Demonstration of flexion and extension at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel axes.

The primary physiologic motion is between the articulation of the sphenoid and the occiput, which moves in a biphasic cycle in response to the pull of the reciprocal tension membrane and the fluctuations of the CSF. During flexion, the sphenoid rotates anteriorly while the occiput rotates posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. During extension, the sphenoid rotates posteriorly while the occiput rotates anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) CORRECT:

Compression of the SBS is a pathological strain pattern in which the sphenoid and occiput bones are pushed toward each other, significantly limiting the motion of the SBS. This type of strain is characterized by diminished or absent CRI during flexion and extension of the SBS.
Image Description:

Demonstration of compression (restriction of motion) at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis.

In compression, the movement of the sphenoid and occiput is restricted. Lateral compressions can also be present that cause unilateral impaction.
questions.hint: This type of SBS dysfunction most commonly results from direct head trauma (especially to the front or back of the head) or birth trauma.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the office with a persistent headache following a motor vehicle accident. He reports that he struck his forehead on the windshield. The headache is located in the occipital region and is accompanied by a feeling of pressure behind the eyes. The patient denies any loss of consciousness, vomiting, or visual disturbances after the accident. His past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Physical examination reveals:

No focal neurologic deficits
Contusion on the forehead without lacerations or active bleeding
Restricted flexion and extension of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) on vault hold
Low rate and amplitude of the cranial rhythmic impulse (CRI)

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Compression of the fourth ventricle is a craniosacral technique that increases the motion, rate, and amplitude of the CRI, making it the treatment of choice for patients with diminished CRI (e.g., due to SBS compression). First, the patient is placed in a supine position with the physician seated at the head of the table. Next, the physician places the thenar eminences just below the nuchal line, medial to the mastoid processes, and draws back the occipital bone. Then, they apply gentle pressure to encourage the extension phase and resist the flexion phase of the CRI. The position is held until the CRI ceases (i.e., point of stillness). Finally, on resumption of the CRI, the physician gently allows for normal extension and flexion to occur before releasing.

B) INCORRECT:

The V spread technique is a craniosacral treatment used to release restricted or impacted peripheral sutures (e.g., frontonasal, occipitomastoid). This patient's physical examination findings suggest compression of the SBS rather than restricted peripheral sutures, making another treatment more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Decompression of the occipital condyles is a craniosacral technique used to balance the reciprocal tension membrane at the hypoglossal canal, thereby normalizing the function of the hypoglossal nerve (cranial nerve XII). This patient's physical examination findings suggest compression of the SBS rather than hypoglossal nerve dysfunction, making another treatment more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Venous sinus technique is a craniosacral treatment used to improve venous drainage from the head. This patient's examination findings suggest compression of the SBS rather than impaired venous drainage, making another treatment more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Temporal rocking is a craniosacral technique used to treat external or internal rotation of the temporal bone. This patient's examination findings suggest compression of the SBS rather than a primary dysfunction of the temporal bones, making another treatment more appropriate.
questions.hint: This patient presents with persistent headache, restricted motion of the SBS, and low rate and amplitude of the CRI following minor head trauma, which is consistent with compression of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS).

questions.text: A 1-week-old female newborn is brought to the office by her mother because of problems breastfeeding. The mother reports that for the past 3 days, the patient has had difficulty latching and her sucking has been weak. She denies any vomiting, abdominal distention, diarrhea, or fever. The patient was born at term via vaginal delivery without any complications. Physical examination findings, including inspection of the oral cavity, are normal, and organic causes of feeding difficulty are ruled out. The most appropriate osteopathic manipulative technique for this newborn is

choices.text: muscle energy to the temporomandibular joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sphenopalatine ganglion technique is used to treat patients with thick nasal discharge, which this patient does not have.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fourth ventricle (CV4) is an osteopathic cranial manipulative technique used to influence the flow of cerebrospinal fluid and improve the cranial rhythmic impulse (CRI). This technique is used for certain cranial conditions, such as sphenobasilar synchondrosis compression, which can result from childbirth. However, this patient does not have an abnormal CRI, making a different technique more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle energy to the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is used to treat TMJ dysfunction, which manifests with jaw pain and restricted motion of the jaw. TMJ dysfunctions most commonly affect adults and they are uncommon in newborns. Additionally, muscle energy is an active technique, which requires the patient to follow instructions and make voluntary movements.

D) INCORRECT:

Temporal rocking is a craniosacral technique used to treat external or internal rotation of the temporal bone, which this patient does not have.

E) CORRECT:

Occipital condyle compression can result from childbirth and affect the function of the hypoglossal nerve, causing feeding difficulties in newborns. Occipital condyle decompression balances the reciprocal tension membrane at the hypoglossal canal, restoring the function of the hypoglossal nerve. This improves latching and sucking during breastfeeding.

To perform occipital condyle decompression, the physician holds the patient's head in their palms, with the index and middle fingers contacting the condylar processes on both sides. Gentle cephalad and lateral traction is then applied at the base of the occiput.
questions.hint: Difficulty latching and sucking in newborns can be due to altered hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) function.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the office because of headaches for the past 6 months. The headaches are typically worse in the afternoon, and over-the-counter medications have only provided minimal relief. The patient denies any trauma. She is interested in exploring osteopathic manipulative treatment as a potential solution. During the physical examination, you note a strain at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) and external rotation of the parietal and temporal bones. Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Increased anteroposterior diameter of the head
Extension of the midline cranial bones
Caudad deviation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased anteroposterior diameter of the head occurs in craniosacral extension. During craniosacral extension, the parietal and temporal bones are internally rather than externally rotated.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) manifests with diminished or absent cranial rhythmic impulse during extension and flexion of the SBS. SBS compression typically occurs after trauma to the head (e.g., during birth) and would not explain this patient's cranial examination findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Extension of the midline cranial bones (i.e., sphenoid, occiput, ethmoid, and vomer) occurs in craniosacral extension. During craniosacral extension, the parietal and temporal bones are internally rather than externally rotated.

D) INCORRECT:

Caudad deviation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) occurs in craniosacral extension. During craniosacral extension, the parietal and temporal bones are internally rather than externally rotated.

E) CORRECT:

During craniosacral flexion, the SBS moves cephalad pulling the dura in the same direction, which causes the sacral base to move posteriorly (i.e., sacral counternutation). Concurrently, the parietal and temporal bones rotate externally, and the sphenoid and occiput demonstrate flexion. This leads to a decrease in the anteroposterior diameter of the head.

While flexion and extension are normal physiological movements of the SBS, they can also present as strain patterns. This patient most likely has a flexion dysfunction of the SBS (i.e., the SBS is stuck in flexion and restricted in extension).
questions.hint: External rotation of the paired bones (i.e., temporal and parietal) is characteristic of craniosacral flexion, which occurs when the SBS moves into flexion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of intermittent headaches. The pain is dull and usually located at the base of the skull. Ibuprofen provides minimal pain relief. History reveals minor head trauma from a skiing accident 1 year ago. She denies any visual disturbances, nausea, or vomiting. Physical examination reveals no focal neurologic deficits. On cranial vault hold, the right index and little fingers spread apart and move inferiorly, while the left index and little fingers come closer together and move superiorly. Which of the following cranial strain patterns is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern characterized by twisting at the SBS, i.e., the sphenoid and occiput rotating in opposite directions on an anteroposterior axis. Torsions are named according to the greater wing of the sphenoid that is more superior. In left torsion, the sphenoid rotates clockwise and the occiput rotates counterclockwise (when viewed from posterior). During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's left index finger would be positioned higher than the right and the right little finger would be positioned higher than the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) CORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation is a physiological sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) dysfunction characterized by two simultaneous motions, causing cranial asymmetry. Sidebending occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in opposite directions around two vertical axes, causing them to separate on one side of the SBS. The side of the head where the SBS separates feels convex on palpation (i.e., the fingers on that side will spread apart during the vault hold). Rotation occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around an anteroposterior (AP) axis. The sphenoid and occiput rotate toward the convexity around the AP axis, causing the greater wing of the sphenoid and the squamous part of the occiput to move inferiorly on the convex side of the head (i.e., the index and little finger on that side move inferiorly during the vault hold). This strain pattern is named according to the side of convexity.

In a right sidebending and rotation dysfunction, the examiner's right index finger (which palpates the greater wing of the sphenoid) and the right little finger (which palpates the squamous part of the occiput) spread apart and move inferiorly, while the left index and little fingers come closer together and move superiorly in the vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Compression of the SBS is a pathological strain pattern, often resulting from trauma to the front or back of the head. In SBS compression, the sphenoid and occiput are pushed toward each other, leading to restricted flexion and extension and a decreased or absent CRI in the cranial vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of compression (restriction of motion) at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis.

In compression, the movement of the sphenoid and occiput is restricted. Lateral compressions can also be present that cause unilateral impaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Left sidebending and rotation would result in the examiner's left index and little fingers spreading further apart and moving inferiorly, while the right index and little fingers would come closer together and move superiorly during vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Vertical strains are pathological strain patterns characterized by the rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around two transverse axes. This strain pattern often results from trauma to the top of the head or below the mouth. Vertical strains are named according to the position of the sphenoid base relative to the occiput. In an inferior vertical strain, the base of the sphenoid moves inferiorly relative to the basilar occiput. During the cranial vault hold, the greater wings of the sphenoid would move superiorly; the examiner's index fingers would move superiorly and the little fingers would move inferiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern characterized by twisting at the SBS, i.e., the sphenoid and occiput rotating in opposite directions on an anteroposterior axis. Torsions are named according to the greater wing of the sphenoid that is more superior. In right torsion, the sphenoid rotates counterclockwise and the occiput rotates clockwise (when viewed from posterior). During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's right index finger would be positioned higher than the left and the left little finger would be positioned higher than the right.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a cranial strain pattern caused by movement of the sphenoid and occiput around three separate axes.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of recurring headaches for the past month. She mentions that the headaches are worse when she reads on her computer. Acetaminophen provides minimal relief. She denies any history of trauma or recent illness. Physical examination shows cranial asymmetry. On cranial vault hold, the left index and little fingers spread apart and move inferiorly, while the right index and little fingers come closer together and move superiorly. Which of the following sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) somatic dysfunctions is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Right sidebending and rotation would result in the examiner's right index and little fingers spreading further apart and moving inferiorly, while the left index and little fingers would come closer together and move superiorly during vault hold.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

B) INCORRECT:

Vertical strains are pathological strain patterns characterized by the rotation of the sphenoid and occiput in the same direction around two transverse axes. This strain pattern often results from trauma to the top of the head or below the mouth. Vertical strains are named according to the position of the sphenoid base relative to the occiput. In a superior vertical strain, the base of the sphenoid moves superiorly relative to the basilar occiput. During the cranial vault hold, the greater wings of the sphenoid would move inferiorly; the examiner's index fingers would move inferiorly and the little fingers would move superiorly.
Image Description:

Demonstration of a superior and inferior shear at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 2 parallel transverse axes.

In a superior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate anteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The black line shows the basisphenoid is higher at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

In an inferior shear, the sphenoid and occiput rotate posteriorly at the sphenobasilar junction. The white line shows the basisphenoid is lower at the SBS compared to the basiocciput.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

C) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern characterized by twisting at the SBS, i.e., the sphenoid and occiput rotating in opposite directions on an anteroposterior axis. Torsions are named according to the greater wing of the sphenoid that is more superior. In left torsion, the sphenoid rotates clockwise and the occiput rotates counterclockwise (when viewed from posterior). During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's left index finger would be positioned higher than the right and the right little finger would be positioned higher than the left.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

D) CORRECT:

Sidebending and rotation is a physiological SBS dysfunction characterized by two simultaneous motions, causing cranial asymmetry. Sidebending occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in opposite directions around two vertical axes, causing them to separate on one side of the SBS. The side of the head where the SBS separates feels convex on palpation (i.e., the fingers on that side will spread apart during the vault hold). Rotation occurs when the sphenoid and occiput rotate in the same direction around an anteroposterior (AP) axis. The sphenoid and occiput rotate toward the convexity around the AP axis, causing the greater wing of the sphenoid and the squamous part of the occiput to move inferiorly on the convex side of the head (i.e., the index and little finger on that side move inferiorly during the vault hold). This strain pattern is named according to the side of convexity.

In a left sidebending and rotation dysfunction, the examiner's left index finger (which palpates the greater wing of the sphenoid) and the left little finger (which palpates the squamous part of the occiput) spread apart and move inferiorly, while the right index and little fingers come closer together and move superiorly in the vault hold
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right side bending and rotation at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis 2 parallel vertical and 1 anterior-posterior axes.

In a left side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate leftward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the right.

In right side bending and rotation, the sphenoid and occiput rotate rightward around the anterior-posterior axis (shown with orange arrows) and side bend outward around two parallel vertical axes (shown with blue and green arrows). The sphenoid and occiput are closer on the left.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.

E) INCORRECT:

Torsion is a physiological strain pattern characterized by twisting at the SBS, i.e., the sphenoid and occiput rotating in opposite directions on an anteroposterior axis. Torsions are named according to the greater wing of the sphenoid that is more superior. In right torsion, the sphenoid rotates counterclockwise and the occiput rotates clockwise (when viewed from posterior). During the cranial vault hold, the examiner's right index finger would be positioned higher than the left and the left little finger would be positioned higher than the right.
Image Description:

Demonstration of left and right torsion at the sphe­nobasilar synchondrosis around 1 anterior-posterior axis.

In a left torsion, the left greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior. In a right torsion, the right greater wing of the sphenoid is more superior.

Movement of the cranial bones is exaggerated for demonstrative purposes.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a cranial strain pattern caused by movement of the sphenoid and occiput around three separate axes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the osteopathic clinic because of recurrent migraine headaches for the past 3 months. The patient denies any trauma. Medications offer only temporary relief and he is interested in trying osteopathic manipulative treatment. Physical examination reveals a strain at the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS); the sacral base is tilted anteriorly. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Cephalad deviation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis
Internal rotation of the parietal and temporal bones
Decreased anteroposterior diameter of the head
Flexion of the sphenoid and occiput

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cephalad deviation of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) occurs in craniosacral flexion. However, during craniosacral flexion, the sacral base is tilted posteriorly into counternutation.

B) CORRECT:

During craniosacral extension, the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) moves caudad pulling the dura in the same direction, which causes the sacral base to tilt anteriorly into nutation. Concurrently, the paired bones (i.e., the temporal and parietal bones) rotate internally and the sphenoid and occiput are extended. This leads to an increase in the anteroposterior diameter of the head.

While flexion and extension are normal physiological movements of the SBS, they can also present as strain patterns. This patient most likely has an extension dysfunction of the SBS (i.e., the SBS is stuck in extension and restricted in flexion).

C) INCORRECT:

A decreased anteroposterior diameter of the head is associated with craniosacral flexion. However, during craniosacral flexion, the sacral base is tilted posteriorly into counternutation.

D) INCORRECT:

Flexion of the midline cranial bones (i.e., sphenoid, occiput, ethmoid, and vomer) occurs in cranial flexion. However, during craniosacral flexion, the sacral base is tilted posteriorly into counternutation.

E) INCORRECT:

Compression of the sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) manifests with diminished or absent cranial rhythmic impulse during extension and flexion of the SBS. SBS compression typically occurs after trauma to the head (e.g., during birth) and would not explain this patient's sacral examination findings.
questions.hint: The sacral base tilts anteriorly into nutation during craniosacral extension, which occurs when the SBS moves into extension.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the office with headaches and neck pain that began after a motor vehicle collision 2 months ago. The patient was rear-ended by another car while stationary at a red light. There were no signs of injury initially but she developed unremitting nausea 1 month ago. She has no history of direct trauma to the head. She has a past medical history of primary dysmenorrhea, ulcerative colitis with bloody diarrhea, and stress incontinence, all of which are poorly controlled. She is currently being evaluated for Sjogren syndrome by her rheumatologist because of persistent dry eyes and dry mouth. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 60/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. On osteopathic structural examination, the physician finds:

Deeper occipital sulcus on the left that resolves with extension of the occipitoatlantal (OA) joint
Tissue texture changes and fascial restriction in the suboccipital area
Trigger point in the left sternocleidomastoid muscle

The physician decides to treat the patient with suboccipital release, which improves the patient's headache and neck pain. This treatment is also most likely to improve which of her other symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diarrhea due to ulcerative colitis involves the descending and rectosigmoid colon, which receive parasympathetic innervation from the pelvic splanchnic nerves, not the vagus nerve. Diarrhea may be alleviated using a different osteopathic manipulative technique that addresses parasympathetic innervation.

B) CORRECT:

Nausea is a common manifestation of vagus nerve dysfunction, which is a potential consequence of OA joint somatic dysfunction. Suboccipital release relieves fascial restriction across the suboccipital triangle, which reduces edema and pain, and normalizes the function of the vagus nerve, which can alleviate nausea. Whiplash, which is likely present in this patient, can cause OA, atlantoaxial, and/or C2 joint somatic dysfunctions.

C) INCORRECT:

Lacrimation is mediated by parasympathetic branches of the trigeminal and facial cranial nerves, not the vagus nerve. These fibers travel through the superior orbital fissure and internal acoustic meatus and would not be affected by suboccipital release.

D) INCORRECT:

All reproductive structures (aside from the ovaries and testes) receive parasympathetic innervation from the pelvic splanchnic nerves, not the vagus nerve. Dysmenorrhea may be relieved using a different osteopathic manipulative technique that addresses parasympathetic innervation (e.g., sacral rocking).

E) INCORRECT:

The bladder and lower ureters receive parasympathetic innervation from the pelvic splanchnic nerves, not the vagus nerve. Urinary incontinence would not be relieved by suboccipital release but may be treated using a different osteopathic manipulative technique that addresses parasympathetic innervation.
questions.hint: An occipital sulcus that is deeper on the left and resolves with extension of the OA joint indicates an OA joint somatic dysfunction. This condition may lead to dysfunction of the cranial nerves that exit via the jugular foramen, such as the vagus nerve, which can be relieved using suboccipital release.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the office because of a persistent ringing sensation in her left ear and occasional episodes of dizziness for the past 2 months. She denies any recent head trauma or infections. Vital signs are normal. Otoscopic examination reveals gray and translucent tympanic membranes. Neurological examination shows decreased hearing on the left. CT scan of the head is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following cranial osteopathic techniques is most likely to improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lift techniques are used to balance membranous tension. The frontal lift technique can be used to treat patients with dysfunction of the frontal, ethmoid, and/or maxillary sinuses but would not help to relieve vestibulocochlear nerve dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fourth ventricle is used to improve the motion of the cranial rhythmic impulse in conditions such as sphenobasilar synchondrosis (SBS) compression. SBS compression is often caused by trauma to the back or front of the head and manifests with decreased cranial flexion and extension amplitude. This patient has no history of trauma or evidence of SBS compression.

C) INCORRECT:

The parietal lift technique is used to help balance membranous tension but would not help to relieve vestibulocochlear nerve dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Decompression of the occipital condyles relieves condylar compression and balances the reciprocal tension membrane at the hypoglossal canal, restoring the function of the hypoglossal nerve, not the vestibulocochlear nerve. Condylar compression usually occurs in newborns as a result of childbirth.

E) CORRECT:

In the absence of trauma or infection, altered vestibulocochlear nerve function may be due to restriction of the temporal bone. Temporal rocking is a craniosacral technique used to treat temporal bone dysfunctions. This technique can resolve restriction of the temporal bone, thereby restoring the function of the vestibulocochlear nerve and relieving any associated symptoms.

To perform temporal rocking, the patient is placed in the supine position and the physician holds the patient's head in their palms, with the thumbs placed just anterior to the mastoid process. Gentle posteromedial traction is applied alternately to the inferior and superior aspects of the mastoid process until the movement on both sides synchronizes.
questions.hint: Tinnitus (ringing sensation in the ear), dizziness, and decreased hearing can be due to altered vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) function.
